slides.title: Welcome to ACCA PM
slides.content:
# Performance Management (PM)

PM covers **advanced management accounting** for decision-making.

## What You Will Learn

- **ABC** - Activity-based costing
- **Target Costing** - Market-driven
- **Transfer Pricing** - Internal transactions
- **Performance** - Modern measures

## Syllabus Areas

| Area | Weight |
|------|--------|
| Decision making | 25% |
| Costing systems | 25% |
| Budgeting | 20% |
| Performance | 30% |

slides.title: Activity-Based Costing
slides.content:
# ABC Costing

## Traditional vs ABC

| Traditional | ABC |
|-------------|-----|
| Volume-based | Activity-based |
| Single OAR | Multiple cost pools |
| Simple | More accurate |

## ABC Process

```
1. Identify activities
2. Assign costs to pools
3. Identify cost drivers
4. Calculate driver rates
5. Charge to products
```

## Cost Drivers

| Activity | Driver |
|----------|--------|
| Purchasing | Number of orders |
| Setup | Number of setups |
| Inspection | Number of inspections |
| Storage | Space occupied |

slides.title: Target Costing
slides.content:
# Target Costing

## Market-Driven Pricing

```
Target Selling Price (market)
- Target Profit Margin
= Target Cost
```

## Cost Gap

```
Estimated Cost - Target Cost = Cost Gap

If gap exists, reduce through:
- Value analysis
- Design changes
- Process improvement
```

## Value Engineering

| Technique | Focus |
|-----------|-------|
| Functional analysis | Eliminate waste |
| Design review | Simplify design |
| Supplier involvement | Input from chain |

## Benefits

- Customer-focused
- Proactive cost management
- Cross-functional teams

slides.title: Target Costing Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Target cost equals target price minus?

slides.title: Life Cycle Costing
slides.content:
# Life Cycle Costing

## Product Life Cycle

```
Introduction -> Growth -> Maturity -> Decline
```

## Costs Across Lifecycle

| Stage | Major Costs |
|-------|-------------|
| Development | R&D, design |
| Introduction | Marketing |
| Growth | Production |
| Maturity | Support, variants |
| Decline | Disposal |

## Benefits

- Full cost visibility
- Better pricing decisions
- Environmental costs included

## Maximizing Returns

- Reduce design costs
- Minimize production costs
- Extend maturity phase
- Plan for decline

slides.title: Throughput Accounting
slides.content:
# Throughput Accounting

## Theory of Constraints

The bottleneck limits system output.

## Key Measures

| Measure | Formula |
|---------|--------|
| Throughput | Sales - Material cost |
| Conversion cost | All other costs |
| TPAR | Throughput / Time on bottleneck |

## TPAR Decision

```
TPAR > 1: Product profitable
TPAR < 1: Consider discontinuing
```

## Managing Bottleneck

- Maximize bottleneck use
- Reduce setup times
- Improve quality
- Add capacity

slides.title: Environmental Accounting
slides.content:
# Environmental Costing

## Environmental Costs

| Category | Examples |
|----------|----------|
| Prevention | Training, audits |
| Detection | Monitoring, testing |
| Internal failure | Waste treatment |
| External failure | Fines, cleanup |

## Benefits of Tracking

- Cost reduction opportunities
- Regulatory compliance
- Stakeholder expectations
- Competitive advantage

## Input/Output Analysis

```
Inputs (materials, energy)
    |
    v
    Process
    |
    +-> Products
    +-> Waste/emissions
```

slides.title: Transfer Pricing
slides.content:
# Transfer Pricing

## What is Transfer Price?

Price charged between divisions for internal trades.

## Methods

| Method | Formula |
|--------|--------|
| Market-based | External market price |
| Cost-based | Cost + markup |
| Negotiated | Agreed between divisions |

## Minimum Transfer Price

```
Marginal cost
+ Opportunity cost of transfer
= Minimum transfer price
```

## Goal Congruence

- Align divisional and company goals
- Motivate managers
- Enable fair evaluation

slides.title: Transfer Pricing Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Minimum transfer price includes marginal cost plus?

slides.title: Divisional Performance
slides.content:
# Divisional Measures

## Return on Investment

```
ROI = Profit / Capital Employed x 100
```

## Residual Income

```
RI = Profit - (CE x Cost of Capital)
```

## ROI vs RI

| ROI | RI |
|-----|----|
| Percentage | Absolute amount |
| Easy comparison | Size-adjusted |
| May reject good projects | Better decisions |

## Economic Value Added

```
EVA = NOPAT - (CE x WACC)
```

slides.title: Balanced Scorecard
slides.content:
# Balanced Scorecard

## Four Perspectives

| Perspective | Key Question |
|-------------|-------------|
| Financial | How do we look to shareholders? |
| Customer | How do customers see us? |
| Internal | What must we excel at? |
| Learning | How can we improve? |

## Example Measures

| Perspective | Measure |
|-------------|--------|
| Financial | ROI, revenue growth |
| Customer | Satisfaction, retention |
| Internal | Cycle time, quality |
| Learning | Training hours, innovation |

## Benefits

- Balanced view
- Links strategy to operations
- Non-financial measures

slides.title: Pricing Strategies
slides.content:
# Pricing Decisions

## Pricing Methods

| Method | Approach |
|--------|----------|
| Cost-plus | Full cost + markup |
| Marginal | Variable cost + contribution |
| Market | Competitor-based |
| Value | Customer-perceived value |

## Price Elasticity

```
Elasticity = % change in demand / % change in price

Elastic: > 1 (demand sensitive)
Inelastic: < 1 (demand stable)
```

## Optimal Price

```
MR = MC for profit maximization

Price = a - bQ
MR = a - 2bQ
```

slides.title: Limiting Factor Analysis
slides.content:
# Scarce Resources

## Single Limiting Factor

```
Contribution per unit /
Limiting factor per unit
= Contribution per limiting factor

Rank products by this ratio
```

## Example

```
Product A: $20 cont, 2 labor hours
Product B: $15 cont, 1 labor hour

A: $20/2 = $10 per hour
B: $15/1 = $15 per hour

Priority: B first, then A
```

## Multiple Limiting Factors

Use linear programming:
- Objective function
- Constraints
- Feasible region
- Optimal point

slides.title: Limiting Factor Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: When ranking products with a limiting factor, prioritize products with highest?

slides.title: Risk and Uncertainty
slides.content:
# Decision-Making Under Uncertainty

## Expected Value

```
EV = Sum of (Probability x Outcome)
```

## Decision Trees

```
        [Decision]
       /          \\
     Option A    Option B
       |           |
    [Chance]    [Chance]
      / \\         / \\
   Good  Bad   Good  Bad
```

## Sensitivity Analysis

How much can variables change before decision changes?

## Risk Attitudes

| Attitude | Preference |
|----------|------------|
| Risk-seeking | Higher variance |
| Risk-neutral | Expected value |
| Risk-averse | Lower variance |

slides.title: Beyond Budgeting
slides.content:
# Modern Budgeting

## Traditional Budget Criticisms

- Time-consuming
- Gaming behavior
- Outdated quickly
- Focus on cost cutting

## Rolling Budgets

```
Continuously updated:
Month 1 actual -> Add Month 13 budget
```

## Beyond Budgeting

| Principle | Meaning |
|-----------|--------|
| Relative targets | Beat competitors |
| Adaptive planning | Rolling forecasts |
| Resources on demand | Not fixed |

slides.title: Variance Analysis Advanced
slides.content:
# Advanced Variances

## Sales Variances

```
Sales Price Variance:
(Actual - Budget price) x Actual qty

Sales Volume Variance:
(Actual - Budget qty) x Standard contribution
```

## Mix and Yield

```
Mix Variance:
(Actual mix - Std mix) x Std cost x Actual total

Yield Variance:
(Actual yield - Std yield) x Std cost
```

## Planning and Operating

Split variances into:
- Planning (budget error)
- Operating (efficiency)

slides.quizQuestion: What does the mix variance measure?
